comments:
This course is an introduction to concepts and methods of Calculus for students with little or no previous Calculus experience. Topics covered in the course include polynomial and elementary transcendental functions and their applications; derivatives, extremum problems, curve sketching, and approximations; integrals and the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus.

Most students were taking the class to fulfill the College of Arts and Sciences Formal Reasoning requirement; as a result, there was a wide range of previous experience with the subject. A few students commented that those with less experience “are at a great disadvantage.”

While students generally felt that Professor Sesum was knowledgeable, many students felt that her teaching style made learning difficult. Several students reported that Professor Sesum moved too quickly through the material and “focused too much on theoretical approaches,” instead of practice problems, which made tests and homework harder. A common complaint was that Professor Sesum “didn’t engage [her] students,” though one student said she “improved in her style of teaching over the course of the semester.”

Even students who were familiar with Calculus felt that the course was harder than they expected. One student reported that “midterms ranged from very easy to quite difficult.” Several students recommended reviewing from the textbook after lecture to solidify the lesson.

This course is an introduction to concepts and methods of Calculus for students with little or no previous Calculus experience. Topics covered in the course include polynomial and elementary transcendental functions and their applications; derivatives, extremum problems, curve sketching, and approximations; integrals and the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus.

Most students were taking the class to fulfill the College of Arts and Sciences Formal Reasoning requirement; as a result, there was a wide range of previous experience with the subject. A few students commented that those with less experience “are at a great disadvantage.”

Students raved about Professor Rimmer’s teaching style, describing him as “engaging,” “exciting,” and “wonderful.” Students were equally impressed with his availability outside of class. As one student wrote, “You could almost always stop by his office and ask a quick question, which he would kindly answer.” Students also reported that Professor Rimmer’s posted notes were extremely helpful. As one student summed up, “Rimmer can teach Calculus to a dog. And the dog wouldn’t even have to be that smart.”

Even students who were familiar with Calculus felt that the course was harder than they expected. One student reported that “midterms ranged from very easy to quite difficult.” Several students recommended reviewing from the textbook after lecture to solidify the lesson.

This course is an introduction to concepts and methods of Calculus for students with little or no previous Calculus experience. Topics covered in the course include polynomial and elementary transcendental functions and their applications; derivatives, extremum problems, curve sketching, and approximations; integrals and the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus.

Most students were taking the class to fulfill the College of Arts and Sciences Formal Reasoning requirement; as a result, there was a wide range of previous experience with the subject. A few students commented that those with less experience “are at a great disadvantage.”

Students agreed that Professor Wylie “was [willing] to spend ample amounts of time with students to go over course material that was not understood.” Though unanimous when it came to his high availability, students had mixed feelings regarding his teaching style. Some students thought that Professor Wylie was “a bit disorganized” and “should work on explaining the material better to his students.” On the other hand, he was also described as “a great teacher who was very knowledgeable about the subject.”

Even students who were familiar with Calculus felt that the course was harder than they expected. One student reported that “midterms ranged from very easy to quite difficult.” Several students recommended reviewing from the textbook after lecture to solidify the lesson.
